module.title: Healthy vs. Unhealthy Relationships
module.description: Learn how to recognize healthy and unhealthy relationship patterns through simple stories and clear signs of safety and respect.

theme.title: A Tale of Two Relationships
theme.context: Aisha notices her two friends experiencing very different relationships. Emily and Kai talk things out calmly, trust each other, and support each other's independence. Zoe and Ryan, however, show control and fear—Zoe cancels plans, feels pressured to respond instantly, and becomes anxious when Ryan blames or intimidates her. These differences help Aisha see what healthy and unhealthy relationships look like in real life.
theme.question: How do trust, independence, and safety change the way a relationship feels?

concepts.title: Trust, Respect, and Independence
concepts.definition: Healthy relationships are built on mutual respect, trust, and the freedom for each person to have their own friends, hobbies, and choices.
concepts.why_it_works: When both people trust each other and respect boundaries, the relationship feels balanced instead of controlling, and each person can be honest without fear.

tutorial.good_story: Emily and Kai sometimes disagree, but they talk calmly and listen. When Emily wants time with friends or alone, Kai encourages her and trusts her choices. Their trust and respect help both of them feel confident and free.
tutorial.bad_story: Ryan checks Zoe’s phone, expects instant replies, and gets upset when she spends time with friends. He blames her for his anger and says things like "You made me do that." Zoe feels anxious, watched, and less independent over time.

summary.summary_content: In healthy relationships, people trust each other, speak kindly, and respect each other's time, space, and choices. If one person tries to control the other, ignores their needs, or makes them feel guilty, the relationship becomes unbalanced and unhealthy.
summary.next_chapter_intro: Next, let’s look at safety and early warning signs that tell you whether a relationship is healthy or harmful.

quizzes.question: Which behavior best shows trust and respect?
options: Checking a partner’s phone to see who they talk to
Encouraging a partner to spend time with their friends
Blaming a partner for your own anger
Raising your voice to "win" an argument
quizzes.explanation: Encouraging independence and friendships shows trust and respect for the other person’s choices.

quizzes.question: Which example shows respect for someone’s boundaries?
options: Pressuring someone to always reply right away
Expecting to know their passwords
Supporting their need for personal time
Getting angry when they spend time with friends
quizzes.explanation: Respecting someone’s personal time and space is a clear sign of healthy boundaries and trust.

concepts.title: Safety, Green Flags, and Red Flags
concepts.definition: Healthy relationships feel emotionally and physically safe. Green flags are healthy signs of kindness and equality, while red flags warn of control, fear, or disrespect.
concepts.why_it_works: Knowing what safety, green flags, and red flags look like helps you notice patterns early so you can choose safe relationships and get support if something feels wrong.

tutorial.good_story: Emily feels safe telling Kai when something bothers her. He listens, stays calm, and works with her to solve problems. They respect each other’s feelings, cheer for each other’s wins, and share decisions fairly. Their relationship shows many green flags.
tutorial.bad_story: Zoe feels scared when Ryan yells, blames her, and isolates her from friends. He acts possessive, refuses to take responsibility for hurtful actions, and Zoe feels she has to keep him calm. Even without physical harm, these red flags make the relationship unsafe.

summary.summary_content: Green flags include kindness, honesty, safety, and respect for your boundaries. Red flags include name-calling, guilt-tripping, jealousy, isolation, and unpredictable anger. Paying attention to these signals helps you stay safer and choose healthier connections.
summary.next_chapter_intro: Now that you know the key signs of healthy and unhealthy relationships, you’ll learn how to stay safe and reach out for help when something feels wrong.

quizzes.question: Which situation shows emotional safety?
options: Being afraid to speak up during disagreements
Feeling comfortable sharing your feelings
Being pressured to do something you don't want to do
Being yelled at during arguments
quizzes.explanation: Emotional safety means you can share your thoughts and feelings without fear of being attacked or punished.

quizzes.question: Which of these are red flags in a relationship?
options: Isolation from friends
Extreme jealousy
Calm problem-solving together
Deflecting responsibility for harmful behavior
quizzes.explanation: Isolation, extreme jealousy, and blaming others for hurtful actions are warning signs of unhealthy or abusive dynamics.

reflection.module_summary: Healthy relationships are built on trust, respect, independence, and emotional and physical safety. Green flags show supportive patterns; red flags warn of control, fear, or disrespect. By noticing how you feel and how others treat you, you can move toward relationships that support your well-being and away from those that cause harm.
reflection.learning_advice: As you continue learning, notice which relationships in your life feel safe, respectful, and balanced, and which ones bring fear, guilt, or pressure. This awareness is a powerful first step toward healthier connections.

module.title: Communication and Boundaries
module.description: Learn simple tools to speak up, listen well, and protect your boundaries in everyday relationships.

theme.title: Late-Night Texting
theme.context: At midnight, Sam’s friend Jordan kept texting about a game. Exhausted but caring, Sam waited until morning and said, "I feel really tired when I get texts after 11 PM because it keeps me awake." Jordan shared that late-night texting helped with his anxiety. Together they agreed Jordan would text earlier or save longer messages for the next day. Both friends felt heard and respected.
theme.question: How could you use your words to respect both your needs and your friend’s feelings in a situation like this?

concepts.title: Expressing Feelings Clearly
concepts.definition: You can express your feelings clearly by first noticing what you feel and then using simple "I" statements to explain the situation and why it matters to you.
concepts.why_it_works: Naming your emotions and using "I feel" instead of blame helps calm strong feelings, reduces defensiveness, and makes it easier for others to understand you.

tutorial.good_story: Maya felt upset when her sister took her headphones without asking. She paused, took a breath, and said: "I feel frustrated when my things are taken without permission because I needed them this morning. Can you please ask next time?" Her sister apologized and agreed to check first.
tutorial.bad_story: When Jordan’s presentation was criticized, he immediately snapped, "You’re so unfair! You think you’re perfect!" and stormed out. Later, he wished he had named his feelings and explained why the feedback hurt instead of attacking the other person.

summary.summary_content: Clear communication starts with knowing what you feel, then using the pattern: "I feel [emotion] when [situation] because [reason]." This keeps the focus on your experience instead of blaming the other person and helps hard conversations stay calmer.
summary.next_chapter_intro: Now that you can share your own feelings more clearly, let’s learn how to really listen when others share theirs.

quizzes.question: Your friend keeps interrupting you. Which is the best "I" statement?
options: You never let me finish talking!
I feel frustrated when I'm interrupted because I lose my train of thought.
Stop being so rude all the time.
Why can't you just listen for once?
quizzes.explanation: This option follows the "I feel [emotion] when [situation] because [reason]" pattern and focuses on your experience instead of attacking the other person.

quizzes.question: Which three parts make up an effective "I" statement?
options: Blame, accusation, demand
Feeling, situation, reason
Problem, person, punishment
Complaint, criticism, consequence
quizzes.explanation: An effective "I" statement includes how you FEEL, the SITUATION that triggers it, and the REASON why it affects you.

quizzes.question: Which actions do NOT help calm strong emotions before you speak?
options: Ignoring your feelings
Naming and acknowledging your emotions
Blaming others for how you feel
Keeping feelings bottled up
quizzes.explanation: Ignoring feelings, blaming others, and bottling emotions up tend to increase stress. Naming emotions is what helps the brain start to calm down.

concepts.title: Listening Well and Respecting Boundaries
concepts.definition: Active listening means giving someone your full attention and trying to understand their point of view. Respecting boundaries means accepting their limits and “no” without pressure or guilt.
concepts.why_it_works: When people feel listened to and know their boundaries will be respected, they are more likely to trust you, share honestly, and stay in healthy relationships.

tutorial.good_story: When Alex shared worries about an upcoming test, Jamie put down their phone, made eye contact, and said, "So you’re nervous because you missed last week’s classes? That makes sense—want to review together?" Later, when friends pressured Lee to skip class, Lee said, "No thanks, I need to keep my attendance up. You all have fun though!" Their friends accepted the boundary, and both Alex and Lee felt respected.
tutorial.bad_story: Emma tried to explain why she felt left out, but Kate kept scrolling social media and changed the subject to her own weekend. In another situation, Casey felt unsafe sharing their phone password, but gave in after their partner insisted. Emma felt ignored, and Casey felt their boundary had been crossed.

summary.summary_content: Listening well means putting distractions away, not interrupting, and checking that you understood. Respecting boundaries means accepting someone’s limits, even when you’re disappointed. True friends listen, adjust, and don’t push past a clear "no."
summary.next_chapter_intro: You’ve learned how to speak clearly, listen with care, and protect your limits. Next, you’ll put these skills together in real-life scenarios.

quizzes.question: Which of these behaviors do NOT show active listening?
options: Planning your response while they talk
Checking your phone occasionally
Paraphrasing what they said to confirm understanding
Changing the subject to something that happened to you
quizzes.explanation: Paraphrasing shows real listening. Planning your reply, checking your phone, or switching the topic back to yourself all pull attention away from the speaker.

quizzes.question: What is a clear sign that someone is NOT respecting your boundary?
options: They ask for clarification about your limits.
They accept your "no" without argument.
They keep pushing after you've said no.
They share their own boundaries too.
quizzes.explanation: Continuing to push, guilt-trip, or pressure you after you’ve clearly said no shows they are not respecting your limits.

reflection.module_summary: Think of a recent disagreement or tense moment you had with someone. How did you express your feelings, and how did you listen to theirs? If you reacted on impulse or stayed silent, how might you use an "I" statement, a short pause to calm down, or a clear boundary next time?
reflection.learning_advice: Practice these skills in low-stress situations first—for example, when choosing a movie or planning a hangout. The more you use clear "I" statements, active listening, and kind boundaries, the more natural they will feel in harder moments.
